name: Gwangjang Market
summary: Made globally famous by Netflix, this market is a battleground between authentic deliciousness and tourist exploitation. While the mung bean pancakes remain legendary, specific stalls (especially the 'Netflix lady' knife noodles) have been caught overcharging tourists and serving smaller portions.

red_flags.evidence: "Vendors were caught serving smaller portions to foreigners for the same price. It was a national scandal." (Korea JoongAng Daily)
"You cannot move. You eat with strangers' elbows in your ribs." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The crispy bindaetteok at Sun-hui's stall is still the best in the city." (Seoul Eats)
"Despite the crowds, the energy of steaming pots and shouting ajummas is infectious." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: The knife noodle lady was rude and the portion was tiny. Go to the stalls on the side streets instead.
Yes it's touristy, but the raw beef bibimbap is life changing. Just avoid the main intersection.

embedding_text: Gwangjang Market in Seoul, South Korea. market. mixed. Netflix fame brought crowds and some overcharging scandals (knife noodles). However, Mung Bean Pancakes and Raw Beef remain authentic and high quality. Red flags: Tourist surcharges, Extreme overcrowding. Positives: Bindaetteok is elite, Vibrant energy.

name: Myeongdong Street Food Alley
summary: A dedicated tourist zone selling 'Korean' street food that locals never eat (lobster tails, rainbow cheese). Prices are 2-3x higher than other districts, and the flavors are standardized for international palates.

red_flags.description: Double the price of normal markets
red_flags.evidence: "₩15,000 for a lobster tail that is mostly shell. Pure robbery." (Reddit)
"Locals do not eat rainbow cheese toast. This is theme park food." (Seoulistic)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you are intimidated by local markets, this is an easy, safe entry point." (Travel Blog)
"You can try 20 different things in a 500m walk." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Fun to look at, but don't eat here. Go to Namdaemun for real food at half the price.
Expensive but the egg bread was tasty and hot.

embedding_text: Myeongdong Street Food Alley in Seoul, South Korea. street_food. tourist_trap. Designated tourist zone selling expensive, Instagram-focused food (lobster, rainbow cheese). Locals avoid. Prices are 2-3x higher than average. Red flags: Double the price, Food made for Instagram. Positives: Convenient and English-friendly, Huge selection.

name: Khaosan Road Street Food
summary: The backpacking center of the universe. The Pad Thai sold from carts here is famously ketchup-sweet, pre-cooked, and inferior to literally any other street corner in Bangkok. It serves one purpose: soaking up cheap alcohol.

red_flags.evidence: "It's orange, sweet, and mushy. Designed for drunk palates only." (Eating Thai Food)
"They charge you 100 Baht just to take a photo of the scorpions." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "You don't go for the food, you go for the chaos and meeting people." (Nomadic Matt)
"Buckets of cocktail for $5. Cannot beat the price to get wasted." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: The Pad Thai tasted like ketchup noodles. Avoid the carts here.
I ate a scorpion and drank a bucket. 10/10 night, 0/10 food.

embedding_text: Khaosan Road Street Food in Bangkok, Thailand. street_food. tourist_trap. Backpacking center. Pad Thai is ketchup-sweet and pre-cooked. Scorpions are props for photos. Red flags: Worst Pad Thai in Thailand, Scorpion sellers. Positives: Legendary party vibe, Dirt cheap alcohol.

name: Nishiki Market
summary: Once 'Kyoto's Kitchen', it is now a congested tunnel of tourists eating food on sticks. Traditional pickle shops are being replaced by souvenir stands. Locals generally avoid it due to the 'tourist pollution' and difficulty walking.

red_flags.evidence: "Grandmothers can't do their shopping here anymore because of the wall of tourists." (Japan Times)
"You get yelled at for walking with food, but there is nowhere to stand." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "Aritsugu knives are still world-class if you can reach the counter." (Kyoto Foodie)
"The colors and variety of seafood are great for photos." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: It's just a crush of people. We couldn't stop to look at anything.
Go at 9am when it opens. The soy milk donuts are still worth it.

embedding_text: Nishiki Market in Kyoto, Japan. market. tourist_trap. Formerly 'Kyoto's Kitchen', now a congested tourist tunnel. Locals avoid due to crowds. Traditional shops replaced by souvenirs. Red flags: Locals pushed out, No eating while walking rule. Positives: Some historic shops remain, Visual spectacle.

name: Hanoi Train Street
summary: A narrow residential street where cafes operate illegally on active train tracks. It is dangerous, frequently closed by police, and cafe owners aggressively force tourists to buy drinks to 'allow' them to stand there.

red_flags.evidence: "A lady blocked the public road and said 'No coffee no photo'." (TripAdvisor)
"Police barricade the entrances randomly. You might travel there for nothing." (Vietnam Coracle)

positive_signals.evidence: "Feeling the train brush past your nose is a genuine adrenaline rush." (Travel Blog)
"It is undeniably the best photo you will take in Hanoi." (Instagram)

sample_reviews.text: Dangerous and stressful. Cafe owners are aggressive. Not worth the risk.
We got lucky and saw the train. Scariest and coolest thing ever.

embedding_text: Hanoi Train Street in Hanoi, Vietnam. attraction. tourist_trap. Narrow street with illegal cafes on active train tracks. Dangerous, often closed by police, and owners force drink purchases. Red flags: Forced cafe purchases, Unpredictable closures. Positives: Unique thrill, Photogenic.

name: Ben Thanh Market
summary: The most famous landmark in Saigon is also a high-pressure sales zone. Vendors grab your arm, prices are marked up 300% for tourists, and the food section is overpriced compared to street stalls just one block away.

red_flags.evidence: "They grab your arm and won't let go. Very aggressive." (TripAdvisor)
"They asked 500k dong for a T-shirt. I bought it for 100k elsewhere." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's iconic and right in the center. Good for a quick look." (Lonely Planet)
"If you are good at haggling, you can find everything here." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Horrible experience. The ladies are so aggressive. Go to Tan Dinh market instead.
Good food if you know the prices, but be prepared to fight for a deal.

embedding_text: Ben Thanh Market in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. market. tourist_trap. High-pressure sales zone. Vendors are physically aggressive and markups are 300%. Locals shop at Tan Dinh. Red flags: Physical aggression, The 'Tourist Tax'. Positives: Central landmark, One-stop souvenir shop.

name: Finns Beach Club
summary: A massive bamboo structure in Canggu that feels more like a crowded airport terminal than a beach club. Minimum spends are high, it is packed shoulder-to-shoulder, and the 'VIP' areas offer little respite from the chaos.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to commit to spending millions of rupiah just to sit on a towel." (The Bali Bible)
"The pool water was cloudy and full of drunk people. Zero relaxation." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "Great DJ and sunset vibes if you like to party hard." (Instagram)
"Despite the crowds, the waiters were fast and friendly." (Google Maps)

sample_reviews.text: Soulless money machine. Go to La Brisa for a better vibe.
Expensive but the sunset view with a cocktail was nice. Just very busy.

embedding_text: Finns Beach Club in Bali, Indonesia. bar. tourist_trap. Massive, overcrowded beach club in Canggu. Feels like an airport terminal. High minimum spends and cloudy pools. Red flags: Exorbitant minimum spend, Overcrowded pool. Positives: Party energy, Efficient staff.

name: Warung Babi Guling Ibu Oka
summary: Made legendary by Anthony Bourdain. Once a humble stall, it is now a commercial operation catering to busloads of tourists. The roast pig (Babi Guling) is still decent, but locals argue the skin is often cold and better versions exist at Pak Malen or Ibu Rambug.

red_flags.evidence: "Skin was chewy, not crispy. Felt like it was cooked hours ago." (Food Blog)
"Locals stopped coming years ago when the prices doubled." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "It put Babi Guling on the map for the world." (Eater)
"A safe, clean place to try the dish for the first time." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: It's fine, but Pak Malen is way better and spicier. Ibu Oka is for beginners.
Delicious pork! We arrived early and got the fresh skin.

embedding_text: Warung Babi Guling Ibu Oka in Bali, Indonesia. restaurant. mixed. Made famous by Bourdain. Now commercialized and tourist-heavy. Pork is decent but often cold/chewy. Locals prefer Pak Malen. Red flags: Mass produced feel, Only tourists eat here. Positives: Cultural icon, Safe introduction.

name: Rainbow Mountain (Vinicunca)
summary: The ultimate 'Instagram vs Reality' trap. Photos show vibrant colors, but the reality is often a muddy, grey trek at dangerous altitude (5,200m) with hundreds of people. The colors are only visible under specific weather conditions.

red_flags.evidence: "If it rains or snows (which is often), it's just a brown mud hill. Zero colors." (TripAdvisor)
"Tour agencies push this on people who just arrived. Altitude sickness is rampant." (Travel Safety Blog)

positive_signals.evidence: "On a clear day, the striations are geologically fascinating." (NatGeo)
"The entrance fees go directly to the indigenous communities managing the land." (Local Guide)

sample_reviews.text: Heavily edited photos lied to me. It was grey, cold, and I threw up from altitude.
Hard hike but worth it for the view of the Red Valley nearby.

embedding_text: Rainbow Mountain (Vinicunca) in Cusco, Peru. attraction. tourist_trap. Instagram vs Reality disappointment. Often muddy/grey unless weather is perfect. Dangerous altitude (5,200m) for unacclimatized tourists. Red flags: Weather dependency, Dangerous altitude. Positives: Unique geological formation, Supports local community.

name: Central
summary: Voted the #1 Restaurant in the World. It is expensive and difficult to book, but it is the opposite of a trap. The menu is a deep research project into Peru's biodiversity, executing flavors found nowhere else on earth.

red_flags.evidence: "You need to be online the second reservations open, months in advance." (Eater)
"A meal here costs a month's salary for a local." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The altitude-based menu is a masterpiece of edible geography." (World's 50 Best)
"They use ingredients from the Amazon and Andes that even locals haven't seen." (New York Times)

sample_reviews.text: It's an investment, but it changed how I understand food. Not just a meal, an expedition.
Proud that Peruvian food is on the world stage. Virgilio is a genius.

embedding_text: Central in Lima, Peru. restaurant. local_gem. Voted #1 Restaurant in the World. Expensive and hard to book, but offers unmatched biodiversity research on a plate. Red flags: Booking is nearly impossible, Very expensive. Positives: Unmatched culinary innovation, Deeply Peruvian ingredients.

name: Café del Mar
summary: Occupies a prime spot on the historic city walls. You pay an entrance fee just to access the bar, the cocktails are watery and overpriced, and the service is notoriously arrogant. You are paying strictly for the sunset.

red_flags.evidence: "Paying a cover charge to enter a bar is ridiculous, and the drinks were bad." (TripAdvisor)
"Waiters act like they are doing you a favor. Ignored us for 30 minutes." (Google Maps)

positive_signals.evidence: "Okay, the view of the sunset over the Caribbean is admittedly perfect." (Lonely Planet)
"Sitting on the 400-year-old wall with the sea breeze is nice." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Buy a beer from a street vendor and sit on the wall 10 meters away for free. Same view.
Terrible drinks, but great photos. One time thing.

embedding_text: Café del Mar in Cartagena, Colombia. bar. tourist_trap. Prime spot on city walls. Charging entrance fees for watery drinks and arrogant service. Paying strictly for the sunset. Red flags: Cover charge, Arrogant service. Positives: The Sunset View, Breezy historic setting.

name: Andrés Carne de Res (Chía)
summary: A 2,000-seat maximalist steakhouse and nightclub outside Bogota. It is chaotic, surreal, and expensive, but unlike its city branches, the original Chía location is a beloved pilgrimage site for locals celebrating birthdays.

red_flags.evidence: "It's a $30 Uber ride/hour drive from Bogota. You need a designated driver." (WikiTravel)
"Prices are high, you are paying for the show more than the steak." (Degusta)

positive_signals.evidence: "It's Alice in Wonderland meets a rave. There is nothing like it." (Eater)
"Every Bogotano has celebrated a birthday here. It's an institution." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Total madness. Confetti, actors, dancing on tables. The steak was actually good too.
Don't go to the DC location, go to Chia. It's the only real one.

embedding_text: Andrés Carne de Res (Chía) in Bogota, Colombia. restaurant. local_gem. 2,000-seat maximalist steakhouse/nightclub. Chaotic, surreal, and beloved by locals for celebrations. Red flags: Far from city center, Expensive. Positives: Unmatched party vibe, Locals love it.

name: Escadaria Selarón
summary: A vibrant mosaic staircase created by artist Jorge Selarón. It is a stunning piece of public art, but the crowds are suffocating, making it nearly impossible to get a photo without 20 other people in it.

red_flags.evidence: "Expect to wait in line to take a photo on the main steps." (TripAdvisor)
"Do not wander off the stairs. The surrounding streets can be sketchy." (Local Safety Guide)

positive_signals.evidence: "The tiles from around the world are fascinating to look at close up." (Lonely Planet)
"It costs nothing and is an iconic symbol of Rio." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful art but ruined by the influencers. Go at 7am or don't bother.
Iconic. We found a tile from our home country!

embedding_text: Escadaria Selarón in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. attraction. mixed. Vibrant mosaic staircase. Stunning public art, but suffocating crowds make photos difficult. Surrounding area can be unsafe. Red flags: Crowded photo struggle, Safety in surrounding area. Positives: Artistic detail, Free.

name: Confeitaria Colombo
summary: A grand cafe from 1894 with colossal mirrors and stained glass. It is a 'Time Trap'—the atmosphere is majestic, but the pastries and coffee are average and overpriced compared to modern bakeries.

red_flags.evidence: "The coxinha was dry and the coffee was bitter. You eat the decor." (Rio Times)
"Queue wrapped around the block in the heat." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "One of the most beautiful cafes in the world. A visual masterpiece." (Architectural Digest)
"It feels like the Belle Epoque. Historic value is undeniable." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Go for tea and look at the ceiling. Don't expect a gourmet meal.
Tourist trap with bad service. We waited 20 minutes for the bill.

embedding_text: Confeitaria Colombo in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. cafe. mixed. Grand cafe from 1894. Majestic atmosphere, but pastries and coffee are average and overpriced. Red flags: Average food, Long queues. Positives: Stunning architecture, Living history.

name: Jemaa el-Fnaa Food Stalls
summary: The famous night market is a sensory overload of aggressive touts. The numbered food stalls serve pre-cooked, mediocre tagines often linked to 'Marrakech Belly' (food poisoning). Locals eat in the side streets, not the center.

red_flags.evidence: "Touts will physically block your path and guilt you into sitting." (Rough Guides)
"Food sits out all day. Known locally as the diarrhea lottery." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The smoke, the lights, the noise—it is a spectacle you must see (from a distance)." (NatGeo)
"The juice carts (separate from food stalls) are cheap and fresh." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: Do not eat at the numbered stalls! We got sick. Go to a restaurant with a terrace instead.
Just buy the orange juice ($0.40) and walk around. The food is a scam.

embedding_text: Jemaa el-Fnaa Food Stalls in Marrakech, Morocco. street_food. tourist_trap. Sensory overload of aggressive touts. Food is pre-cooked, mediocre, and linked to illness. Locals eat elsewhere. Red flags: Extreme harassment, Hygiene concerns. Positives: Incredible energy, Fresh Orange Juice Carts.

name: Pyramids Camel Ride
summary: Notorious for scams. Handlers will quote a low price to get on, then demand a fortune to let you get off. The animals are often mistreated, and the experience is high-stress rather than magical.

red_flags.evidence: "He refused to make the camel kneel down until I paid $50 extra." (TripAdvisor)
"Camels looked malnourished and were beaten." (PETA/Travel Blogs)

positive_signals.evidence: "It is the classic Egypt photo with the pyramids in the back." (Instagram)
"Riding where pharaohs walked is a nice thought." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Nightmare. I was harassed the entire time. Walk or take an Uber to the panorama point.
If you pre-book with a reputable guide, it's fine. Do not negotiate on the street.

embedding_text: Pyramids Camel Ride in Cairo, Egypt. tour. tourist_trap. Notorious for 'hostage scams' (pay to get off). Animals often mistreated. High-stress experience. Red flags: Hostage scam, Animal welfare. Positives: Iconic photo op, Ancient transport.

name: Sydney Fish Market
summary: The largest fish market in the Southern Hemisphere is a chaotic, overpriced destination. While the seafood is fresh, it is cooked in heavy grease, served on styrofoam, and eaten while fighting off aggressive seagulls in a parking lot setting.

red_flags.evidence: "$30 for a greasy basket of fish and chips? You can get better at any beach shop." (Broadsheet)
"The birds are a menace. They snatch food from your hands." (Sydney Morning Herald)

positive_signals.evidence: "If you buy the raw oysters or sashimi, quality is top tier." (Timeout Sydney)
"The sheer variety of species on display is impressive." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Locals call it a trap. The new building might fix it, but for now, it's a dirty parking lot.
Loved the sashimi platter. Just avoid the deep fried stuff.

embedding_text: Sydney Fish Market in Sydney, Australia. market. tourist_trap. Largest fish market in region but chaotic and overpriced. Cooked food is greasy, seagulls are aggressive. Red flags: Overpriced cooked food, Seagulls and crowding. Positives: Fresh oysters/Sashimi, Huge selection.

name: Hobbiton Movie Set
summary: Expensive ($90+ USD) and in the middle of nowhere, yet it consistently ranks as a highlight. The attention to detail is obsessive (real vegetable gardens), and the tour concludes with a complimentary ale at the Green Dragon Inn.

red_flags.evidence: "It is very expensive for a 2 hour walking tour." (TripAdvisor)
"It's a long drive from Auckland just for this." (Lonely Planet)

positive_signals.evidence: "The set is maintained to perfection. It feels real." (The One Ring)
"Even if you aren't a fan, the landscape is stunning." (Travel Blog)

sample_reviews.text: I expected a trap but I was blown away. The level of detail is insane.
Rushed through in a group, but the Green Dragon drink was a nice touch.

embedding_text: Hobbiton Movie Set in Matamata, New Zealand. attraction. local_gem. Expensive and remote, but obsessive attention to detail makes it a highlight. Includes drink at Green Dragon Inn. Red flags: High ticket price, Remote location. Positives: Immaculate maintenance, Magical experience.

name: Grand Bazaar
summary: One of the oldest malls in the world, now a labyrinth of fake designer bags and overpriced lamps. Shopkeepers are aggressive, and prices are 3-4x higher than markets used by locals (like Kadıköy).

red_flags.evidence: "Spices cost 4x more here than at the Egyptian Bazaar." (Culinary Backstreets)
"Mostly counterfeit bags and cheap souvenirs made in China." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The painted ceilings and history are worth the walk." (Lonely Planet)
"4,000 shops. You can get lost for hours." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Go for the architecture, buy nothing. It's a rip-off city.
Fun to haggle if you know what you're doing, but exhausting.

embedding_text: Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, Turkey. market. tourist_trap. Oldest mall in the world, now a labyrinth of fake goods and aggressive sellers. Prices are 3-4x higher than local markets. Red flags: Tourist markup, Fake goods. Positives: Architectural wonder, Endless browsing.

name: Hafiz Mustafa 1864
summary: Despite being in all the tourist centers (Sultanahmet, Taksim), this dessert chain maintains incredible quality. Their Baklava and Turkish Delight are fresh, using real honey and pistachios, and locals still buy gift boxes here.

red_flags.evidence: "More expensive than neighborhood spots, but you pay for consistency." (Istanbul Eats)
"Service can be slow due to the volume of customers." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The pistachio-to-dough ratio is perfect. Not too sweet." (Serious Eats)
"I always bring Hafiz Mustafa when visiting family abroad." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Best baklava I've ever had. Open 24/7 which is dangerous.
Touristy but quality. The milk puddings are underrated.

embedding_text: Hafiz Mustafa 1864 in Istanbul, Turkey. cafe. local_gem. Dessert chain maintaining incredible quality despite tourist locations. Fresh Baklava and Turkish Delight. Locals buy gifts here. Red flags: Pricey for Istanbul, Busy/Chaotic. Positives: High quality ingredients, Reliable gift.

name: Gardens by the Bay
summary: A futuristic botanical garden that looks like a sci-fi movie set. While the Cloud Forest dome requires a ticket, the Supertree Grove is free. It manages to be a massive tourist attraction that is also genuinely beloved for its engineering and beauty.

red_flags.evidence: "Avoid weekends and public holidays, it's a zoo." (Honeycombers)
"Cloud Forest is amazing, Flower Dome is just a greenhouse." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The world's tallest indoor waterfall is breathtaking." (Condé Nast Traveler)
"You can see the Supertree light show for free every night." (Timeout)

sample_reviews.text: Avatar in real life. The Cloud Forest is worth every penny.
Bring a picnic and sit under the Supertrees. Best free activity in SG.

embedding_text: Gardens by the Bay in Singapore. attraction. local_gem. Futuristic botanical garden. Cloud Forest is a marvel; Supertree Grove is free. Massive attraction but genuinely beloved for engineering and beauty. Red flags: Crowded on weekends. Positives: Cloud Forest waterfall, Free outdoor areas.

name: Bukchon Hanok Village
summary: A historic neighborhood of traditional Korean houses (Hanok) dating back 600 years. It is visually stunning, but the 'over-tourism' has led to conflict with residents who patrol the streets shushing tourists, creating a tense atmosphere.

red_flags.evidence: "Residents wear yellow vests and tell you to be quiet. It feels unwelcoming." (Korea Herald)
"You can't go inside most houses. It's just walking up a hill." (Reddit)

positive_signals.evidence: "The juxtaposition of ancient roofs and modern skyscrapers is unique." (Visit Seoul)
"The view from the top of the hill overlooking Seoul is worth the climb." (TripAdvisor)

sample_reviews.text: Beautiful but I felt guilty being there. Signs everywhere saying 'Be Quiet'.
Go early (8am) before the bus crowds. It's peaceful then.

embedding_text: Bukchon Hanok Village in Seoul, South Korea. attraction. mixed. Historic neighborhood of traditional houses. Visually stunning, but over-tourism creates tense atmosphere with residents (shushing). Red flags: Hostile atmosphere, Just facades. Positives: Preserved architecture, Great views.

name: Leopold Cafe
summary: Immortalized by the novel 'Shantaram' and a site of the 2008 terror attacks. It is packed with tourists seeking the literary connection. The food is average continental/Indian, but the bullet holes in the walls serve as a chilling historical marker.

red_flags.evidence: "Food is overpriced and mediocre. You pay for the Shantaram vibe." (Mumbai Mag)
"Waiters want you to eat and leave. Very noisy." (Zomato)

positive_signals.evidence: "Seeing the bullet holes from 2008 is a powerful, somber experience." (BBC Travel)
"A great place to meet other backpackers and swap stories." (Lonely Planet)

sample_reviews.text: Read the book, went for a beer. It's loud and crowded, but I'm glad I went once.
Overrated. Go to Cafe Mondegar nearby for better vibes and art.

embedding_text: Leopold Cafe in Mumbai, India. cafe. mixed. Immortalized by 'Shantaram' and 2008 attacks. Packed with tourists. Food is average, but bullet holes in walls are a powerful historical marker. Red flags: Average food, Rushed service. Positives: Historical marker, Traveller hub.

name: Fushimi Inari Taisha
summary: The famous 'thousands of red gates' shrine. While the base is swarming with Instagrammers, it is a massive mountain complex. If you hike 30 minutes up, the crowds vanish, leaving a spiritual and atmospheric experience.

red_flags.evidence: "The entrance is a mosh pit of selfie sticks." (Japan Guide)
"Water costs double halfway up the mountain. Bring your own." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "The further you go, the more magical it gets. Silence and red gates." (Matcha-JP)
"Open 24/7. Go at night for a spooky, empty experience." (Reddit)

sample_reviews.text: Don't stop at the bottom! Hike to the crossroads for the view and solitude.
Too many people at the start, but it's iconic for a reason.

embedding_text: Fushimi Inari Taisha in Kyoto, Japan. attraction. local_gem. Famous red gates shrine. Base is crowded, but hiking 30 mins up reveals a spiritual, empty experience. Open 24/7 and free. Red flags: Base is overcrowded. Positives: Spiritual hike, Always open and free.

name: Desa Potato Head
summary: More than just a beach club, it's a creative village with a focus on sustainability. While still expensive and busy, the architecture (made of antique shutters) and zero-waste initiatives give it a soul that competitors lack.

red_flags.evidence: "You have to arrive at 10am to get a bed, or pay for VIP." (The Bali Bible)
"Drinks are London prices in Indonesia." (TripAdvisor)

positive_signals.evidence: "They are zero-waste. The furniture is recycled plastic. Impressive." (Wallpaper*)
"The colosseum of shutters is a design icon." (Design Boom)

sample_reviews.text: Best sunset spot. The music is chill, not aggressive like Finns.
Great vibe but be prepared to pay. Food is small portions.

embedding_text: Desa Potato Head in Bali, Indonesia. bar. mixed. Creative village/beach club. Expensive and busy, but stands out with antique shutter architecture and zero-waste sustainability initiatives. Red flags: Waitlist for daybeds, Expensive cocktails. Positives: Sustainability focus, Architectural gem.
